docs.snippet: ALL those James Bond movies, almost four decades of them, began with Terence Young's DR. NO (1962). In it, Sean Connery, the original Agent 007 and still champ, goes to scenic Jamaica to battle the title supervillain (Joseph Wiseman) and the occas...
docs.lead_paragraph: ALL those James Bond movies, almost four decades of them, began with Terence Young's DR. NO (1962). In it, Sean Connery, the original Agent 007 and still champ, goes to scenic Jamaica to battle the title supervillain (Joseph Wiseman) and the occasional poisonous spider. Ursula Andress is the very first on-screen Bond girl, Honey Ryder (which is a downright subtle name, compared with those that followed), who makes her living stealing Caribbean sea shells to sell in Miami. Naturally she wears a bikini to work -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Channel 7.

docs.snippet: NEIL HANNON, the singer and songwriter who leads the British pop outfit known as the Divine Comedy, is apparently not skilled at keeping track of his personal belongings. In one of his latest compositions, ''Lost Property,'' which appears on the D...
docs.lead_paragraph: NEIL HANNON, the singer and songwriter who leads the British pop outfit known as the Divine Comedy, is apparently not skilled at keeping track of his personal belongings. In one of his latest compositions, ''Lost Property,'' which appears on the Divine Comedy's new album, ''Regeneration,'' he recounts various items he has mislaid over the years. Passports, mobile phones, a pair of tennis rackets, sweaters, asthma inhalers, ''C-class narcotics'' -- the list is long and governed only by the laws of rhyme. Crooning in a rich baritone, Mr. Hannon expresses bewilderment at the way so many possessions have slipped from his grasp. But toward the song's end, he regains them all in a dream. ''I found them,'' he declares as the band builds to a climax, ''all piled up into the sky/ And I cried tears of joy.'' To get so emotional about a bunch of random objects seems more than a little silly. And yet after the song stops, its underlying poignancy lingers in the listener's mind.
docs.abstract: Mac Randall profiles British pop singer and songwriter Neil Hannon and reviews his latest album; photo (M)

headline.main: A British Pop Songwriter Meets America Halfway

docs.snippet: FOLLOWERS of fashion who wept earlier this month at the retirement of Yves Saint Laurent may be in for a long hard decade.    Mr. Saint Laurent, who will present a final retrospective of his collections in Paris on Tuesday, is considered by many t...
docs.lead_paragraph: FOLLOWERS of fashion who wept earlier this month at the retirement of Yves Saint Laurent may be in for a long hard decade. Mr. Saint Laurent, who will present a final retrospective of his collections in Paris on Tuesday, is considered by many to be in a class by himself, as gauged by his influence on contemporary fashion. But he is just one in a generation of designers who emerged in the 1960's and 1970's, became celebrities whose personal lives were chronicled almost as assiduously as those of movie stars, used their names to peddle everything from sunglasses to bedsheets, and are now old enough to qualify for senior citizens' discounts.
docs.abstract: Article, in light of retirement of Yves Saint Laurent, on other fashion designers who emerged in 1960's and 1970's who are reaching retirement age, including Oscar de la Renta, 69, Giorgio Armani, 67, Ralph Lauren, 62, and Calvin Klein, 59; while most have no plans to retire, fashion field is for the young; photos (M)

docs.snippet: The Olympics are a showcase for excellence in many categories -- in strength, in stamina, in grace -- but when it comes to innovative design, the institution has always been strictly junior varsity. From the silly-looking national costumes of the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Olympics are a showcase for excellence in many categories -- in strength, in stamina, in grace -- but when it comes to innovative design, the institution has always been strictly junior varsity. From the silly-looking national costumes of the opening parade to the hammy pageantry of the closing ceremonies, the dominant aesthetic tends to seem like one part Super Bowl Sunday, two parts Epcot Center. Next month's Winter Olympics will include a striking exception to that rule. Many of the athletes representing Canada, Spain, Switzerland and Japan will be outfitted by Eiko Ishioka, a creative director who has won an Oscar, a Grammy and a Cannes Film Award for her artwork, production and costume designs.
docs.abstract: Many of athletes representing Canada, Spain, Switzerland and Japan at Winter Olympics will wear colorful, precision-engineered body suits designed by Eiko Ishioka; drawings (M)

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 01-20-02: GALLERY: DESIGN

docs.snippet: The problem with pure market research has always been that sometimes artists know what we want to see before we do, and sometimes the times change faster than anyone can predict. So in the same way that ''Amélie,'' by a twist of fate, became the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The problem with pure market research has always been that sometimes artists know what we want to see before we do, and sometimes the times change faster than anyone can predict. So in the same way that ''Amélie,'' by a twist of fate, became the message movie of this moment, the New York collections became all at once about a wistful past and an inevitable future. Of course, no designers thought they were living in an age of innocence when they were working on the New York fashion collections. But, as it turns out, they were.
docs.abstract: Style article on how New York fashion collections, which were being shown last Sept 11, became all at once about 'wistful past and an inevitable future,' in same way that French movie Amelie, by twist of fate, became message movie of moment; fashion photos of film's star Audrey Tautou; other photos from collections (M)

docs.snippet: After they resolved a crisis that brought Colombia to the brink of war, it might seem that the government and a powerful rebel group ended up exactly where they started: talking about how to start real talks.    Even though President Andrés Pastr...
docs.lead_paragraph: After they resolved a crisis that brought Colombia to the brink of war, it might seem that the government and a powerful rebel group ended up exactly where they started: talking about how to start real talks. Even though President Andrés Pastrana and rebel commanders agreed to return to the table, a significant step like a cease-fire remains months, perhaps years away. Colombia remains as violent and divided as ever. And even the foreign diplomats who helped broker the deal that averted a wider war have no illusions that it will be easy to end the 37-year-old conflict.
docs.abstract: Analysis: even through Pres Andres Pastrana of Colombia and rebel commanders agree to return to table, significant step like cease-fire remains months, perhaps years, away; Colombia remains as violent and divided as ever; even foreign diplomats who helped broker deal that averted wider war have no illusions that it will be easy to end 37-year-old conflict; one positive development is new, active role of third-party participants (M)

headline.main: Progress In Colombia: New Talks About Talks

docs.snippet: In a tumbledown studio here barely big enough for his work and far too small for the magnitude of his crusade, the sculptor John Houser is putting finishing touches on an American monument that he hopes will break records and uphold tradition.    ...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a tumbledown studio here barely big enough for his work and far too small for the magnitude of his crusade, the sculptor John Houser is putting finishing touches on an American monument that he hopes will break records and uphold tradition. The son of a sculptor who worked on Mount Rushmore, Mr. Houser, 63, envisions his monument -- a 36-foot bronze equestrian statue of a Spanish colonizer who founded the first European settlements in the Southwestern United States -- one day towering over the border between the United States and Mexico with the power of the Statue of Liberty.
docs.abstract: John Houser, sculptor, is working on 36-foot bronze equestrian statue of Juan de Onate, Spanish colonizer who founded first European settlements in Southwestern United States; monument is set to be completed and dedicated in 2003 in El Paso, Tex; project has won support of some important cultural figures, but Indian peole throughout Texas and New Mexico revile Onate, whose brutal treatment of Indians has been acknowledged by historians; Houser says he is 'thunderstruck' by conflict over his project; photo (M)

headline.main: As a Sculpture Takes Shape in Mexico, Opposition Takes Shape in the U.S.

docs.snippet: Two months ago, Jen Davidson and Jean Racine were inseparable friends who laughed at their quirky differences, completed each other's sentences and shared their inner thoughts in times of grief.    Soulmates, they said. They were also the two-time...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Jen Davidson and Jean Racine were inseparable friends who laughed at their quirky differences, completed each other's sentences and shared their inner thoughts in times of grief. Soulmates, they said. They were also the two-time World Cup champions in women's bobsled, complete with pre-Olympic buzz and catchy first names, all wrapped in an attractive package. Together, Jean and Jen were America's wholesome duo in a Got Milk? ad, were depicted on a cereal box and inspired a Visa commercial.
docs.abstract: Hard feelings develop after Jean Racine, American women's bobsled team driver, drops Jen Davidson as brakewoman and replaces her with Gea Johnson; Racine and Davidson, onetime inseparable friends, are no longer speaking; photos (M)

headline.main: A Picture-Perfect Pair Falls Apart in Bobsled

docs.snippet: Ted Demme, a film and television director whose credits included the movie ''Blow,'' died on Sunday while playing basketball. He was 38 and lived in West Hollywood, Calif.    Mr. Demme was taking part in a celebrity basketball game at a private sc...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ted Demme, a film and television director whose credits included the movie ''Blow,'' died on Sunday while playing basketball. He was 38 and lived in West Hollywood, Calif. Mr. Demme was taking part in a celebrity basketball game at a private school when he was stricken, said a spokesman for the Santa Monica-UCLA Medical Center. The cause of death has not been determined, and an autopsy will be conducted, said Lt. Cheryl MacWillie of the Los Angeles County Coroner's Office.
docs.abstract: Ted Demme, film and television director, dies at age 38; photo (S)

headline.main: Ted Demme, 38, Director for TV And for Movies, Including 'Blow'

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The short article ''When Oscar Losers Become Winners'' (Jan. 8) suggests that Oscar-winning screenwriters may have shorter lives than losing nominees because the winners, with their greater success, feel less pressure to take care of their health.
docs.abstract: Dr David Glenwick letter comments on Jan 8 article on relative longevity of Oscar-winning and Oscar-nominated screenwriters; drawing
